Award.AwardTitle: HRRBAA: Development of New Early Miocene Sites in Northern Uganda

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to search for new fossil localities in eastern Uganda to understand the evolutionary processes associated with the origin of hominoids, the group of primates that includes apes and humans. The few known fossil sites in this area have yielded ancient animal and plant communities that include fossils of the oldest known apes. One of these apes,"Morotopithecus," shows evidence of using an upright trunk, the earliest known precursor of bipedalism in humans. Fossil data relevant to human origins is rare and evidence of such evolutionary specializations in apes provides critical insights into our evolution in Africa. Eastern Uganda represents one of the few known areas in the world where evidence has been found and further discoveries are essential.

Although the general locations of known fossil sites were established over 50 years ago, there have been no systematic attempts to explore this area for fossil localities. This has been due to the remote nature of this region, rugged terrain, large areas to reconnoiter (over 500 km2), heavy vegetation during all but the two-month dry season, limited geologic maps, and political instability related to armed livestock raiding. A recent national disarmament campaign has led to improved safety as well as the establishment of new settlements and access roads. Using newly available high-resolution satellite imagery, an extensive survey will be conducted (during the critical dry season) for fossiliferous sediments for the first time, possibly resulting in new sites and new fossils.

The broader impacts of this project include fostering of the career of women paleontologists, who are under-represented in field projects, as well as fostering the careers of African scholars in the form of collaborators and students. Researchers will disseminate their science widely through timely publication, teaching, the training of museum staff and public lectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to search for new fossil localities in eastern Uganda in order to understand the evolutionary processes associated with the origin of hominoids, the group of primates that includes apes and humans. The known fossil sites in this area, spanning the period between ~21 and 19 million years ago, have yielded ancient animal and plant communities that include fossils of the oldest known apes. One of these apes, "Morotopithecus", shows evidence of using an upright torso, the earliest known precursor of bipedalism in humans. Fossil data relevant to human origins is rare and evidence of such evolutionary specializations in apes provides critical insights into our evolution in Africa.  Thus further discoveries are essential.  

Eastern Uganda represents one of the few areas in the world where fossils that will address these questions can be found. Tectonic and volcanic activity in the East African Rift led to lava flows that preserved natural channels containing bones and sediments on the flanks of volcanoes as they formed. Although the general locations of known fossil sites were established over 50 years ago, there have been no systematic attempts to explore this area for fossil localities. In January of 2014, we undertook such an assessment by using newly available high-resolution satellite images superimposed on geological maps, and hand-held GPS devices, to circumnavigate the base of ancient volcanoes.  By traversing the volcanoes at the point of contact between overlying lavas and the Precambrian basement rock, we located exposures of fossil-bearing sediment. Although no mammal-bearing sediments were located, we found invertebrate and plant fossils at several sites. These findings will be used to guide future reconnaissance in this region.  Some areas on the flanks of the volcanoes could not be prospected because of heavy vegetation cover.  We will continue to monitor vegetation cover in those areas in the coming years, in the event these areas become more accessible.

Also during the period covered by the grant, we conducted analysis on the femur (thigh bone) of Morotopithecus.  A newly-discovered femoral shaft fragment recovered at a site on the Moroto volcano fit on to the femur shaft of other femoral fragments first found in 1997. We used linear regression to examine scaling relationships between femoral shaft length and other femoral dimensions.  We found that all apes have shorter femoral shafts relative to joint sizes and shaft width, than do most primates such as monkeys. Morotopithecus resembles apes in having a short shaft. The relatively short femoral shaft length complements earlier interpretations that Morotopithecus used the hindlimbs and forelimbs differently in behaviors such as upright slow climbing.

Finally, we are continuing to investigate the paleoenvironments of the Ugandan sites in order to improve our understanding of the ecological context in which apes and other mammals evolved.  Our studies of the chemical signatures (i.e. stable carbon and oxygen isotopes) preserved in the fossilized teeth of plant-eating mammals suggests these sites may have contained disturbed, seasonal or somewhat “open” woodlands or forests, suggesting early apes were evolving adaptations to survive in broken-canopy conditions. Potential habitat differences among sites, and their relationship to primate communities, will be the focus of future investigations.
